properties.Name: LifeInsurancePolicy
properties.Description:
The written documents of a contract for insurance between the insurance company and the insured. Such documents include forms, endorsements, riders and attachments.

A formal written contract of insurance.

A contract whereby one undertakes to indemnify another, pay or allow a specified amount or a determinable benefit upon determinable contingencies.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Insurance Policy.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Insurance Policy.

Columns.Name: FaceValueAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount of insurance provided by the terms of an insurance contract.

For a life insurance policy, this is the death benefit.

AKA "Business"

Columns.Name: CoverageAmount
Columns.Description: The constant amount of coverage during the length of the policy.

Columns.Name: MultipleIndemnityPercentage
Columns.Description: A percentage that the death benefit under the policy will be increased by a percentage in the event that a specific peril occurs.

Columns.Name: ApprovedDate
Columns.Description: The date upon which the insured met the underwriting standards of the insured in conjunction with the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: AcceptanceDate
Columns.Description: The acceptance date is when the applicant for insurance receives the policy from the insurer and pays the premium.     In life insurance, the initial premium is almost always submitted with the application so issuance of the policy by the insurer constitutes acceptance.

Columns.Name: CoverNoteIssuedDate
Columns.Description: A cover note is similar to a binder and is written by an agent informing the insured that coverage is in effect.

Columns.Name: DeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date that the actual insurance policy was actually placed in the hands, delivered to, the insured.

Columns.Name: AgeChangeDate
Columns.Description:
The date on which a persons age changes for insurance purposes.

In most life insurance contracts this the date midway between the insured's natural birth dates.

On the date of age change, a person's age may change to that of the last birth date, the nearer birth date or the next birth date depending upon the way in which the rating structure has been established by the insurer.

Columns.Name: QuantityDiscountAmount
Columns.Description: A premium discount given for the purchase of a policy with a larger face amount.

Columns.Name: CancellationDate
Columns.Description: The termination of a contract of insurance in force by voluntary act of the insurer or insured in accordance with the provisions in the contract.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyApplicationDate
Columns.Description: The date that the application for the Insurance Policy was made.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyAcceptanceDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Insurance Policy was accepted by the Insurer.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyEffectiveDate
Columns.Description:
The date that the Insurance Policy is in effect, which is based upon Insurability Receipt or Approval Receipt conditions of the policy.

Insurability Receipt - provides that when the applicant pays the initial premium the coverage is in effect on the condition that the applicant provides to be insurable either on the date the application was signed or the date of the medical exam.

Approval Receipt - Coverage is effective only after the application has been approved by the insurer and prior to the policy being delivered to the Policyholder.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyLapseDate
Columns.Description: The date that the policy will lapse or require renewal.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyTerm
Columns.Description: The period of years for which the insurance policy is issued.

Columns.Name: InsurancePolicyTerminationDate
Columns.Description: The date upon which the Insurance Policy will terminate.

Columns.Name: DateAnnuityBenefitPaymentsBegin
Columns.Description: The date that payout benefits are to begin.

Columns.Name: IssuedUntilAge
Columns.Description:
The age at which the insurance will no longer be issued.

Term life insurance provides protection for a specified period of time only - for example, one year, five years or until the insured reaches a specific age.    

Term life insurance provides life insurance protection for a specified period (or term) and pays a benefit only if the insured dies during that period.

Columns.Name: IssuedForNumberYears
Columns.Description:
The number of years for which the Term Insurance policy is issued.

Term life insurance provides protection for a specified period of time only - for example, one year, five years or until the insured reaches a specific age.    

Term life insurance provides life insurance protection for a specified period (or term) and pays a benefit only if the insured dies during that period.

Columns.Name: AccumulationPeriod
Columns.Description:
An annuity has two distinct time periods involved:

(1) Accumulation Period - the time during which funds are being paid into the annuity

(2) Payout Period - is the time when the annuity ceases to be an accumulation vehicle and starts to generate benefit payments on a regular basis.

Columns.Name: PayoutPeriod
Columns.Description:
An annuity has two distinct time periods involved:

(1) Accumulation Period - the time during which funds are being paid into the annuity

(2) Payout Period - is the time when the annuity ceases to be an accumulation vehicle and starts to generate benefit payments on a regular basis.

Columns.Name: PremiumsStartDate
Columns.Description: The date that insurance policy premiums will begin.

Columns.Name: PremiumsEndDate
Columns.Description: The date that insurance policy premiums will end unless renewed or converted.

Columns.Name: InitialInsurancePolicyPremium
Columns.Description: The initial premium assigned to the insurance policy, which is derived from the baseline or 'standard' premium (Standard Premium) against which risks and assessment are added to determine the actual premium.

Columns.Name: CancellationUponNoticePeriod
Columns.Description: The number of days notice that the insurer must provide the insured prior to canceling the policy.

Columns.Name: PremiumsPaymentPeriod
Columns.Description:
The period upon which premiums are payable.

 - weekly
-  monthly
-  quarterly
-  semi-annual
-  annual

Columns.Name: RenewalPeriod
Columns.Description:
The period of regular renewal of the insurance policy.

- monthly
- quarterly
- semi-annual
- annual

Columns.Name: GracePeriod
Columns.Description: A period from the premium due date during which an insurance contract remains in force and the premiums may be paid.

Columns.Name: ReinstatementProvision
Columns.Description: The reinstatement provision allow the insured to reinstate the insurance policy to its original status and values brought up to date upon payment of past premiums and interest due.

Columns.Name: ReinstatementPeriod
Columns.Description: The number of days after lapse of the insurance policy that the insurance policy may be reinstated upon payment of past premiums, interest and evidence of continued insurability.

Columns.Name: MaximumAllowableLoanRate
Columns.Description: The maximum loan rate that may be applied to loans issued in conjunction with the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: FreelookProvisionPeriod
Columns.Description:
The number of days during which a policyholder may examine a newly-issued individual policy of life or health insurance and may surrender it in exchange for a full refund of premium if not satisfied for any reason.

An insurance policy clause dealing with the period of time (usually 10-30 days) during which a policyholder may examine a newly-issued individual policy of life or health insurance and may surrender it in exchange for a full refund of premium if not satisfied for any reason.

Columns.Name: SuicideNonPaymentPeriod
Columns.Description: The number of days at the beginning of the policy during which a death by suicide will result in a non-payment.

Columns.Name: ContestabilityPeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date during which the insurer is not obligated to pay a claim (usually two years), because of material misrepresentations found in the application. A policy becomes "incontestable" when the contestability period is over.

Columns.Name: ContestabilityPeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date during which the insurer is not obligated to pay a claim (usually two years), because of material misrepresentations found in the application. A policy becomes "incontestable" when the contestability period is over.

Columns.Name: IncontestablePeriod
Columns.Description:
The specific number of days after which the insurer shall not be able to contest the statements contained in the application.

An insurance policy clause that provides that after a policy has been in effect for a given length of time, the insurer shall not be able to contest the statements contained in the application.

Columns.Name: FreelookProvisionStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date during which a policyholder may examine a newly-issued individual policy of life or health insurance and may surrender it in exchange for a full refund of premium if not satisfied for any reason.

Columns.Name: FreelookProvisionEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date during which a policyholder may examine a newly-issued individual policy of life or health insurance and may surrender it in exchange for a full refund of premium if not satisfied for any reason.

Columns.Name: CoinsurancePercentage
Columns.Description:
The percentage of losses that will be shared between the insurer and insured.

Reference the Coinsurance Clause.

Columns.Name: EndowmentPeriodYears
Columns.Description: The period of the endowment expressed in years.

Columns.Name: FreelookProvision
Columns.Description: An insurance policy clause dealing with the period of time (usually 10-30 days) during which a policyholder may examine a newly-issued individual policy of life or health insurance and may surrender it in exchange for a full refund of premium if not satisfied for any reason.

Columns.Name: GracePeriodProvision
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy that states the period of time after the due date of a premium during which the policy remains in force with penalty.

Columns.Name: EntireContractProvision
Columns.Description:
An insurance policy clause stating that the entire agreement between the insured and the insurer is contained in the contract, including the application if it is attached, declarations, insuring agreements, exclusions, conditions and endorsements.  

Nothing may be 'incorporated by reference', which means that the policy cannot refer to any outside documents as being part of the contract.

This clause prohibits the insurer from making any changes to the policy via revisions or changes in the company bylaws after the policy has been issued.

Columns.Name: CollateralAssignmentProvision
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy dealing with the assignment of a policy to a creditor as security for a debt.  The creditor is entitled to be reimbursed out of policy proceeds for the amount owed.  The beneficiary is entitled to any excess of policy proceeds over the amount due the creditor in the event of the insured's death.

Columns.Name: WarClauseProvision
Columns.Description: Relieves the insurer of liability or reduces the liability for the specified loss caused by war.

Columns.Name: NarcoticsProvision
Columns.Description: Relieves the insurer of liability or reduces the liability for the specified loss caused by use of narcotics.

Columns.Name: IntoxicantsProvision
Columns.Description: Relieves the insurer of liability or reduces the liability for the specified loss caused by intoxicants.

Columns.Name: IllegalOccupationProvision
Columns.Description: A provision that defines the effect upon the insurance policy by participation of the insured in illegal activities.

Columns.Name: DelayedPaymentProvision
Columns.Description:
A provision that defers payment to the beneficiary for a specified period after the death of the insured with proceeds to be paid to contingent beneficiaries or the estate if the primary beneficiary does not survive the delay.

It is a method of handling common-disaster situations such as the death of the insured and the primary beneficiary occurring in the same accident.   The clause normally states that the beneficiary has to survive the death of the insured by a certain period of time in order to collect.

Columns.Name: PolicyLoanProvision
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy defining the terms under which a loan may be made by the insurance company to the policyholder with the policy cash value assigned as security.

Columns.Name: AssignmentProvision
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy that allows the policyholder to assign benefits to another party.

Columns.Name: SuicideProvision
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy the provides that if the insured commits suicide within a specified period, usually two years after the issue date, the company's liability will be limited to a return of the premiums paid.

Columns.Name: CoinsuranceProvision
Columns.Description: A provision stating that the insured and the insurer will share all losses covered by the policy in a proportion agreed upon in advance.

Columns.Name: AcceleratedBenefitsProvision
Columns.Description: Accelerated Benefits Provisions provide from the early payment of some portion of the policy face amount should the insurer suffer from a terminal illness or injury.

Columns.Name: ContestableProvision
Columns.Description: A provision in an insurance policy establishing the conditions under which or the period of time during which the insurer may contest or void the policy.

Columns.Name: DesignationOfBeneficiaryProvision
Columns.Description: The provision that deals with the terms and conditions by which beneficiary(s) may be designated for the Policy.

Columns.Name: AutomaticPremiumLoanProvision
Columns.Description: The provision authorizes the insurer to automatically pay any premium in default at the end of the grace period and charge the amount paid against the life insurance policy as a policy loan.

Columns.Name: MultipleIndemnityProvision
Columns.Description: A provision that the death benefit under the policy will be increased by a percentage in the event that a specific peril occurs.

Columns.Name: MedicalConditionDeathBenefitPercentage
Columns.Description:
The percentage that the insurance company will pay to the insured upon proof that the pre-specified medical condition exists.

The intent of the accelerated death benefit is to provide the money required to finance medical costs to improve or extend the life of the insured.   

Note:
The remainder of the death benefit is paid to the beneficiary upon the death of the insured as in a traditional life insurance policy.

Columns.Name: SpecificMedicalConditionsStatement
Columns.Description: The specific Medical Condition(s) that are applicable under the associated policy.

Columns.Name: ConsiderationClause
Columns.Description: That part of an insurance contract setting forth the amount of initial and renewal premiums and the frequency of future payments.

Columns.Name: IncontestableClause
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy providing that for certain reasons such as misstatements on the application the company may void a life policy after it has been in force during the insured's lifetime.

Columns.Name: AbsoluteAssignmentClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy stating that the assignee receives full control over the policy and also full rights to its benefits.  When a policy is assigned to secure a debt, the owner retains all rights in the policy in excess of the debt, even though the assignment is absolute in form.

Columns.Name: NonforfeitureOptionClause
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy detailing privileges allowed under terms of a life insurance contract after cash values have been created.

Columns.Name: SimultaneousDeathClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy dealing the simultaneous death of both/all beneficiaries

Columns.Name: OptionToConvertClause
Columns.Description:
The option to convert gives the insured the right to convert or exchange the term policy for a whole life or permanent plan without evidence of insurability.

This exchange involves the issuance of a new whole life policy at a premium that is in line with the insured's age at either the time of the exchange ('attained age method') or at the time when the original term policy was taken out ('original age method')

Columns.Name: PolicyCancellationClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy dealing the terms and conditions for cancellation of the policy.

Columns.Name: InsuringClause
Columns.Description: The part of an insurance contract that states the perils insured against, person(s) covered, locations and the period of the contract.

Columns.Name: OptionToRenewClause
Columns.Description: The option to renew feature allows the policyowner to renew the term of the policy prior to the termination date without providing evidence of insurability.

Columns.Name: PolicyDividendsClause
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy defining the payment method, period and amount of dividends to be paid by the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: PhysicalExamClause
Columns.Description: Indicates that a physical exam is/is not  required for renewal.

Columns.Name: SettlementOptionsClause
Columns.Description:
The part of the insurance policy that determines the settlement option selected for the insurance policy:

- lump-sum cash
- interest-only
- fixed-period
- fixed-amount
- life income

Columns.Name: SpendthriftTrustClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy that states that to the extent permitted by the law, policy proceeds shall not be subject to the claims of creditors of the beneficiary or policyowner.

Columns.Name: MisstatementOfAgeClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy stating that if the insured's age is misstated in an application for insurance, the benefit payable usually is adjusted to what the premiums paid should have purchased.

Columns.Name: MisstatementOfSexClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy stating that if the insured's sex is misstated in an application for insurance, the benefit payable usually is adjusted to what the premiums paid should have purchased.

Columns.Name: FacilityOfPaymentClause
Columns.Description: A part of an insurance policy allowing the company to pay up to $1,000 of benefits or proceeds to any relative appearing entitles to it if there is no beneficiary or if the insured or beneficiary is a minor or legally incompetent.

Columns.Name: PolicyLoanOptionClause
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy defining the terms under which a loan may be made by the insurance company to the policyholder with the policy cash value assigned as security.

Columns.Name: DeathBenefitsProceedsPaymentMethodClause
Columns.Description: A part of the insurance policy defining the method of payment of death benefits for the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: WholeLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description:
A type of Permanent Life Insurance which can provide lifetime protection with a level premium, guaranteed death benefit and guaranteed cash value. Premiums must be paid for as long as the policy is in force. Most Whole Life policies are eligible to receive dividends, if declared and paid. Dividends can be used to reduce or eliminate out-of-pocket premiums

Whole life combines term insurance with an investment component. A whole life policy has two elements: the mortality charge, the part of your premium that pays for the insurance coverage, and a reserve, the investment component that earns interest. As you age, the portion that goes into the reserve decreases while the portion that pays for the mortality charge increases. In addition to interest, many companies credit the reserve with an annual dividend, depending on the insurer's loss experience and investment performance.

The cash surrender value (which is also called the cash value) is what you'd get if you cashed in your policy. If you decide to give up your policy, your cash surrender value can be paid in cash or paid-up insurance. There are several problems with using whole life as a savings vehicle, however. One is that the policy's advertised rate of return, as disclosed in a set of hypothetical numbers called the policy illustration, can have little or no relation to reality. The policy's returns will fluctuate with the markets and will usually be less than returns available from other investments like equity mutual funds. Whole life is extremely expensive, and if you're on a limited budget, you may not be able to afford all the insurance coverage you actually need.

Columns.Name: UniversalLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description:
A Permanent Life Insurance policy which allows you, within limits, to change the death benefit and vary the amount or timing of premium payments. 

A part of your premium can go towards building a cash value that grows at an interest rate that varies over time, but not below a guaranteed minimum. 

Your cash value is available for you to use in a variety of ways, including to pay premiums.

Universal, like whole, combines insurance with savings. 

The savings component, called an accumulation fund, earns interest monthly and is used to pay the mortality charge. 
There are significant drawbacks to universal policies. 

If you pay reduced premiums in the policy's early years, you can be socked for higher charges later on, when you expected to be paying little or nothing. 

The alternative is to drop the policy and withdraw the savings you may have built up. If you drop the policy, you may have to pay a surrender charge

Columns.Name: VariableLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description:
A form of Universal Life Insurance that allows you to invest your cash value in various funding options that invest in such things as stocks and bonds. You decide how your net policy values are invested, and you bear the investment risk. The premium required to maintain the death benefit, and your cash value depends on the performance of the underlying investments.

Variable-life insurance combines a mortality charge with a savings vehicle that you choose from among a number of alternatives offered by your insurer. The savings vehicle is usually one of several investment portfolios that are structured like mutual funds. On average, most companies offer 10 different portfolios, including stock, bond and money-market funds. The insurers often manage these funds themselves, collecting fees for administering the insurance and managing the portfolios.
There are two basic types of variable life. One demands a fixed premium payment. The other, variable-universal life, has a flexible premium like universal life. Remember, though, that variable returns can fluctuate with the financial markets. If the stock market falls, you may find the cash-value portion of your policy with greatly reduced value..

Columns.Name: TermLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Life insurance that does not build up cash value and provides coverage for a specified period of time.

Columns.Name: ReinstatablePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the insurance policy is reinstatable.

Columns.Name: AssignablePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: An indicator indicating that the insurance policy is assignable to a third party.

Columns.Name: AbsoluteAssignmentIndicator
Columns.Description:
Indicates that assignment by a policy owner of all control of and rights in the policy to a third party as been effected.

Indicates that the policy as been transferred to the assignee, which is absolute and irrevocable.

The assignee receives full control over the policy and full rights to its benefits.

Columns.Name: CollateralAssignmentIndicator
Columns.Description: An indicator indicating the collateral has been assigned to a creditor in conjunction with the Insurance Policy.

Columns.Name: ConvertibleTermInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Term insurance that can be exchanged (converted) to a permanent insurance policy at the option of the policy owner without evidence of insurability.

Columns.Name: FixedVariableAnnuityIndicator
Columns.Description:
An indicator indicating that the annuity is a fixed annuity or variable annuity.

Fixed Annuities pay a guaranteed fixed benefit amount to the annuitant.

Variable Annuities are based on non-guaranteed equity investments so the payout value can vary depending upon the underlying investments.   In a variable annuity during the accumulation period, contributions made by the annuitant, minus deductions for expenses, are converted to accumulation units and credited to the individuals account.   The value of each accumulation unit varies depending upon the value of the underlying investments.

Columns.Name: AutomaticPremiumProvisionIndicator
Columns.Description: An indicator that denotes that the automatic premium provision is in effect for the associated insurance policy.

Columns.Name: BeneficiaryChangeAnytimeIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the beneficiary(s) may be changed at any time.

Columns.Name: PaidUpInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Insurance that will remain in force with no additional premiums needed.

Columns.Name: IrrevocableBeneficiaryIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the beneficiary may not be changed or removed from the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: ReturnOfPremiumInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: This type of life insurance is essentially a hybrid between term life and whole life. You buy a return of premium policy for a set amount of time. You make your payments every year, and in the event that you pass away, your heirs are paid the face value of your death benefit. Should you outlive your policy, the insurer sends you a tax-free check for the full amount that you've spent on premiums over the lifetime of your coverage.

Columns.Name: ReinstatementRequiresNewContestablePeriodIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that reinstatement of the insurance policy requires that a new contestable period be defined.

Columns.Name: OptionToConvertIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the insurance policy has the option to convert.

Columns.Name: OptionToRenewIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the insurance policy has the option to renew.

Columns.Name: LevelPremiumTermLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Term Life Insurance for which the premium remains the same for a specific number of years - usually 10, 20 or 30 years. At the end of the specified term, coverage can usually be continued, but the premium payments would increase each year.

Columns.Name: ReEntryOptionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that in a renewable term life policy under which the policyholder is guaranteed to be able to renew his coverage without evidence of insurability at a premium rate specified in the insurance policy.

Columns.Name: SinglePremiumLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description:
Requires one lump-sum, up-front premium and is often guaranteed to remain paid-up throughout the insured's lifetime. 

These policies sometimes don't come with a guarantee that future payments will never be required

Columns.Name: InsuranceWithOtherInsurersIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the policyholder has other insurance policies with other insurers.

Columns.Name: OtherInsuranceThisInsurerIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the policyholder has other insurance policies with the insurer.

Columns.Name: ConditionalContractIndicator
Columns.Description: Payment of benefits is dependent on or a condition of the occurrence of the risk insured against.

Columns.Name: ConversionPrivilegeIndicator
Columns.Description: The right of an individual to convert a group life insurance policy to an individual policy should the individual cease to be a member of the group.

Columns.Name: ParticipatingInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: A life insurance policy that is eligible for dividend payments by the insurer

Columns.Name: ParticipatingNonParticipatingPolicyIndicator
Columns.Description:
Indicates that the insurance policy pays dividends.

It entitles the policyholder to participate in allocations of the insurer's surplus.

Columns.Name: SecondToDieLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: A type of life insurance policy that insures two lives. The death benefit is payable at the second death. Generally, this product is used as a funding vehicle for estate taxes payable at the second death when the unlimited marital deduction is utilized. Also referred to as survivorship policies. Be sure to compare the cost of two separate policies before signing on for one of these.

Columns.Name: AviationExclusionIndicator
Columns.Description: Death due to aviation are excluded from the insurance policy - except typically 'other than a fare-paying passenger'.

Columns.Name: ChangeOfOccupationProvisionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the insurance will/will not remain in effect in case of change of occupation.

Columns.Name: CommutationRightsIndicator
Columns.Description: The right of a beneficiary to receive in one sum the unpaid payments remaining under an installment option which was selected for the settlement of the proceeds or values of a life insurance policy.

Columns.Name: ConvertibleInsuranceIndicator
Columns.Description: A policy that may be changed to another form by contractual provision and without evidence of insurability.

Columns.Name: FullyPaidPolicyIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that this is a limited payment life insurance contract on which all required payment have been made.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: ProceedsSettlementMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Proceeds Settlement Method.

Columns.Name: MecClassificationTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the insurance policy MEC type.

Columns.Name: PremiumTaxTreatmentTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a premium tax treatment type.

Columns.Name: LifeInsuranceProductParticipatoryStatusTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Life Insurance Product Participatory Status Type.

Columns.Name: FacilityOfPaymentProvisionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Facility of Payment Provision.

Columns.Name: BillingCycleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Billing Cycle.

Columns.Name: MasterContractId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Master Contract.

policy.","isNullable":true,"name":"DeathBenefitsProceedsPaymentMethodClause"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"LifeInsurancePolicy.cdm.json/LifeInsurancePolicy","name":"WholeLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A type of Permanent Life Insurance which can provide lifetime protection with a level premium, guaranteed death benefit and guaranteed cash value. Premiums must be paid for as long as the policy is in force. Most Whole Life policies are eligible to receive dividends, if declared and paid. Dividends can be used to reduce or eliminate out-of-pocket premiums

Whole life combines term insurance with an investment component. A whole life policy has two elements: the mortality charge, the part of your premium that pays for the insurance coverage, and a reserve, the investment component that earns interest. As you age, the portion that goes into the reserve decreases while the portion that pays for the mortality charge increases. In addition to interest, many companies credit the reserve with an annual dividend, depending on the insurer's loss experience and investment performance.

The cash surrender value (which is also called the cash value) is what you'd get if you cashed in your policy. If you decide to give up your policy, your cash surrender value can be paid in cash or paid-up insurance. There are several problems with using whole life as a savings vehicle, however. One is that the policy's advertised rate of return, as disclosed in a set of hypothetical numbers called the policy illustration, can have little or no relation to reality. The policy's returns will fluctuate with the markets and will usually be less than returns available from other investments like equity mutual funds. Whole life is extremely expensive, and if you're on a limited budget, you may not be able to afford all the insurance coverage you actually need.","isNullable":true,"name":"WholeLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"LifeInsurancePolicy.cdm.json/LifeInsurancePolicy","name":"UniversalLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A Permanent Life Insurance policy which allows you, within limits, to change the death benefit and vary the amount or timing of premium payments. 

A part of your premium can go towards building a cash value that grows at an interest rate that varies over time, but not below a guaranteed minimum. 

Your cash value is available for you to use in a variety of ways, including to pay premiums.

Universal, like whole, combines insurance with savings. 

The savings component, called an accumulation fund, earns interest monthly and is used to pay the mortality charge. 
There are significant drawbacks to universal policies. 

If you pay reduced premiums in the policy's early years, you can be socked for higher charges later on, when you expected to be paying little or nothing. 

The alternative is to drop the policy and withdraw the savings you may have built up. If you drop the policy, you may have to pay a surrender charge","isNullable":true,"name":"UniversalLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"LifeInsurancePolicy.cdm.json/LifeInsurancePolicy","name":"VariableLifeInsurancePolicyIndicator"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"A form of Universal Life Insurance that allows you to invest your cash value in various funding options that invest in such things as stocks and bonds. You decide how your net policy values are invested, and you bear the investment risk. The premium required to maintain the death benefit, and your cash value depends on the performance of the underlying investments.

Variable-life insurance combines a mortality charge with a savings vehicle that you choose from among a number of alternatives offered by your insurer. The savings vehicle is usually one of several investment portfolios that are structured like mutual funds. On average, most companies offer 10 different portfolios, including stock, bond and money-market funds. The insurers often manage these funds themselves, collecting fees for administering the insurance and managing the portfolios.
There are two basic types of variable life. One demands a fixed premium payment. The other, variable-universal life, has a flexible premium like universal life. Properties.Description:
The written documents of a contract for insurance between the insurance company and the insured. Such documents include forms, endorsements, riders and attachments.

A formal written contract of insurance.

A contract whereby one undertakes to indemnify another, pay or allow a specified amount or a determinable benefit upon determinable contingencies.
